title: Copy-number and gene dependency analysis reveals partial copy loss of wild-type SF3B1 as a novel cancer vulnerability
abstract: Genomic instability is a hallmark of human cancer, and results in widespread somatic copy number alterations. We used a genome-scale shRNA viability screen in human cancer cell lines to systematically identify genes that are essential in the context of particular copy-number alterations (copy-number associated gene dependencies). The most enriched class of copy-number associated gene dependencies was CYCLOPS (Copy-number alterations Yielding Cancer Liabilities Owing to Partial losS) genes, and spliceosome components were the most prevalent. One of these, the pre-mRNA splicing factor <italic>SF3B1</italic>, is also frequently mutated in cancer. We validated <italic>SF3B1</italic> as a CYCLOPS gene and found that human cancer cells harboring partial <italic>SF3B1</italic> copy-loss lack a reservoir of SF3b complex that protects cells with normal <italic>SF3B1</italic> copy number from cell death upon partial <italic>SF3B1</italic> suppression. These data provide a catalog of copy-number associated gene dependencies and identify partial copy-loss of wild-type <italic>SF3B1</italic> as a novel, non-driver cancer gene dependency.
